subject: Re: Testing a class with private constructor
msgSnippet: The object under test is not a singleton.  However I am using XmlBeans and didn t want to commit the class to construct with XmlBeans, so the factory extracts
messageBody:
The object under test is not a singleton. However I am using
XmlBeans and didn't want to commit the class to construct with
XmlBeans, so the factory extracts pertinent info to construct the
object with.

I ended up making the constructor protected, subclassed and exposed
a public constructor for testing.


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Robert Sanheim <rsanheim@g...> wrote:
> True. I've found myself often refactoring away from the strict
> singleton to something more open to testing.
>
> I forgot to mention in my last message - a type-safe enum would be
> another case where a private constructor is ideal, and where you
would
> not want to public-ize it. Maybe the original poster could chime
in
> with the details of the object under test.
>
> - Rob
>
> On 6/23/05, J. B. Rainsberger <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> > Robert Sanheim wrote:
> >
> > > I'm guessing the object is a singleton or something simliar -
in which
> > > case you would not want to make the constructor public -
especially

singleton,
